5. Summary and Conclusion

The long historical scenario summarized in the present entry has
sought to display the complexity of transformism in biology in the
period as it developed independently of the advent of Darwinism. This
history reveals several lines of non-Darwinian transformism that were
current and under discussion in the natural historical sciences which
were converging on larger explanatory theories of the history of life.
It also lends plausibility to the claim of historian Peter Bowler that
without Darwin, life and earth science would still likely have come to
a “science that we could still recognize, although its
components would seem to have different implications, thanks to having
been assembled in a more natural sequence of discovery” (Bowler,
2013, p. 279). It was against this complex background that Darwin
would develop his own theory on the origin and diversification of
forms with emphasis on the principle of natural selection. He would,
however, draw in many ways on these pre-existing discussions in
French, British and even German sources, and reinterpret these issues
against the framework of criticisms that had emerged against
transformism. Further exploration of this will be made in the entry
Darwin: From the Origin of Species to the Descent of
Man.
